subject: Re: [junit] Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: So said  Mike Colbert   on  2002-12-14 ...  ... Based on the above description, I disagree that you practice TDD. If you practiced
messageBody:
So said Mike Colbert <mbcolbert@...> on 2002-12-14
--------------------

<snip />
>Now, I like to keep things simple: I have a Java class. It lives in
>a file. The file lives in a source code repository. It has
>corresponding test code that tests anything that could possibly break
>in the class. Sometimes I check the Java class out of the repository
>and add stuff to it. Since I practice TDD, more than likely I also
>need to add something to the corresponding test code. When I'm done,
>I check the Java class back in, along with the corresponding test
>code. Cruisecontrol detects this and automatically runs a build on
>the build server. If the code passes all the tests, I go home and
>life is good because I know I'll get a paycheck the next week to pay
>rent and buy food.

Based on the above description, I disagree that you practice TDD. If
you practiced TDD, then you would not write, "...likely I also needed
to add something to the corresponding test code." If you practiced TDD,
you would:

1. Write a test
2. Watch it fail
3. Make it pass
4. Refactor

It's the last step that leads you to see that your TestCase is doing
too much is a candidate to be factored into smaller objects.

I have worked on a project where test cases quickly became difficult to
understand because of the massive amount of test setup -- mostly
priming a database with known data. None of our attempts to solve the
problem were entirely satisfying and the team did not agree to let me
test the business logic entirely separately from the persistence
mechanism. The result was this: after not seeing a certain TestCase for
a few days it would take 10 minutes or so to remember or re-understand
what was going on. Also, changes to the test setup had cascading
effects on the rest of the tests. If I had just created a new TestCase,
I could have factored the real commonality up and kept the details
separate. That would certainly have helped, and this explains why I
have adopted that technique as a habit.

>Now, based on those very simple real world requirements, just exactly
>what is it that makes your approach so superior that you will
>immediately discount all others as inadequate?

At this point, I feel that you are being unnecessarily antagonistic.
Rudeness objection. Please tone it down.

>I know, I know, it's in the newsletter and the forthcoming book.
>That's fabulous. But you're preaching to the TDD converted here and
>we have found our own ways, based first on the information currently
>available and second on our own experience.
<snip />

Given that your above statement (way up there) indicates that you do
not practice TDD, but rather that you do something else that is
somewhere similar to TDD, I am not sure that you can directly use your
experience to argue either in favor or against TDD. I apologize if that
is harsh, but I believe it is objectively true. I make no value
judgement: do what you do if it works, but please do not call it TDD.

>I beleive TDD has
>gathered quite a bit of momentum by now and if you have any chance of
>influencing its direction you need to provide a little more than just
>self-referential justification for your approach.

Now you have turned this into an ad-hominem attack. I do not believe
that many of us is interesting in this kind of thing. As a moderator, I
am asking you to tone it down. Just because we do not write
novel-length, in-depth answers to your question does not mean that we
are evading anything. It means that we are busy.

>You say, "This will help us write and organize groups of tests that
>are simpler, cleaner, more understandable, and more maintainable."
>
>These are all noble goals for an approach to TDD. Would you care to
>elaborate on just why you believe you have achieved these goals?

If I were Dave -- and I clearly am not -- I would not take much
interest in justifying myself to someone who so rudely challenges me.
Civilly-worded challenges are perfectly acceptable.

Thank you.
